Type I error: Rejecting Ho when it is true
Type II error: Failing to reject Ho when it is false
Level of significance: increasing alpha, will decrease the probability of creating a Type I error

p-value: the probability of getting a result at least as extreme as the one found in your sample, assuming Ho is true
If p-value is low, reject Ho, we have sufficient evidence for Ha, otherwise we do NOT have sufficient evidence for Ha

Nonparametric methods can be used if the requirements are not met for parametric methods(t.test, chi-square, etc.)

### Tests
<div style="padding-left:125px;color:lightgray;">
<!-- Add your customizations in the area below: -->

[One Sample t test](tTests.html)

Requirements: 

Distribution of sample means is normal

- Sample size >= 30

- qqPlot to check for normality

1) Ho: mu = value; Ha: mu != or > or <

2) Check Requirements - library(car) qqPlot(data$var)

3) t.test(NameOfYourData$Y, mu = YourNull, alternative = YourAlternative, conf.level = 0.95)

4) library(tidyverse) ggplot(data, aes(x=column)) +

  geom_histogram()
  
5) library(mosaic) favstats(data$var)

Non-Parametric:

[Signed-Rank Wilcoxon Test](WilcoxonTests.html) 
    - if requirements are not met for t Test

[One-Way ANOVA](ANOVA.html)

Requirements:

- Each group is normally distributed

- Variance of error term is constant or similar or equal; Residual Plot

Tukey Test
    - used if the ANOVA p-value is significant, to find which specific group is different


Non-Parametric:

[Kruskal-Wallis Test](Kruskal.html)
    - if requirements are not met for ANOVA
